Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genetic Architecture of Covarying Traits
Award.AbstractNarration:
The capacity of organisms to respond to selective pressures on multiple traits is determined in part by the genetic covariances between those traits. This project will map regions of the genome associated with genetic variation in glucosinolate traits in a population of Boechera stricta, a model plant for evolutionary genetics. B. stricta makes several types of glucosinolates, compounds that defend the plant against insect herbivores. By mapping the regions of the genome that control glucosinolate profile in each type of plant tissue, the investigator will determine whether the same or different loci control glucosinolates throughout the plant. Then, using population data at these genomic regions, the amount of covariation in glucosinolate traits controlled by each locus will be determined.

Knowing the genetic architecture of covarying traits is essential in predicting how those traits are able to respond to selection; if one gene controls multiple traits, evolutionary constraints are likely to be stronger than if trait correlations are caused by correlated selective pressures. Genetic covariances have been important to plant breeders, as well, as they may affect the response to artificial selection. Understanding the genetic basis of glucosinolate allocation, which is agriculturally relevant and affects cancer risk in humans, will lend insight into how breeding programs may affect crop plants. This grant will also support training of a young scientist in important genomic techniques and analyses, as well as outreach efforts in traditionally underperforming schools encouraging students, particularly girls, to pursue college and a career in the STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigated the genes underlying evolutionary constraints. Organisms may not be able to respond effectively to all selective pressures; in such cases, particularly when multiple traits are under selection, a population may experience genetic constraints on the evolution of some traits. We investigated constraints on the evolution of glucosinolates, defensive compounds, in Boechera stricta, a wild mustard. We worked within a single population to predict the evolutionary trajectory for glucosinolate profile in leaves and fruits. We found that a single gene controls most of the variation in glucosinolate profile in the population, and that it acts in both leaves and fruits, causing a strong covariance between the two tissues. However, we found antagonistic selection acting on the two tissues; that is, a high level of a specific compound in leaves were favored, but was disadvantageous in fruits. This strongly positive covariance between tissues combined with the observed antagonistic selection caused strong constraints in the evolution of defenses in both tissues; glucosinolate profile was actually predicted to evolve in a maladaptive direction in leaves. 

One gene of major effect, BCMA3, played a large role in these constraints. BCMA3 affects glucosinolate profile in both tissues, and drives the covariance between them. When the effects of BCMA3 were eliminated from the analysis, the genetic constraints were highly reduced, indicating that BCMA3 is driving the constraints as well. 

These genetic constraints reduce the response to selection in the population, meaning that traits change more slowly than they would otherwise. In this case, the constraints may help preserve genetic variation at BCMA3, which has a longstanding polymorphism in the species; the reduced response means that the favored allele will replace the other one at a slower rate. Overall, this project contributes needed empirical data to previous theoretical work on how genetic architecture affects the evolution of multiple co-varying traits.
